awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: Traffic Deconfliction for Smart and Autonomous Unmanned Aircraft Systems in Congested Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Unmanned air vehicle (UAV) operations bring considerable scientific and societal benefits with its applications ranging from package delivery, linear infrastructure inspection, to large-scale environmental monitoring. However, Autonomous UAV operation is not yet allowed by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) without airborne chase aircraft or ground observers to ensure traffic deconfliction, which is complicated and costly. The goal of the proposed project is to enable a given UAV to predict the trajectories of its neighboring UAVs, dynamically assess collision risks, and automatically resolve potential conflicts without the need for constant human supervision. This project seeks to: 1) implement the ability to operate a multitude of UAVs without direct human oversight in a way that might satisfy future FAA regulations; 2) establish a mathematical representation of a UAV traffic that can be scaled to handle a complex, heterogeneous, and high-dimensional traffic; and 3) mature UAV operations for civil and commercial applications in harmony with existing commercial air traffic.

The project aims at developing a real-time, distributed decision-making algorithm, the Dynamic Network-based Probabilistic Route Planner (DNPRP), for autonomous operation of multiple UAVs in congested environments. The key technical components will include 1) a cloud-sourced database system for UAV data sharing, 2) an algorithm for virtual and dynamic UAV network discovery, 3) time-dependent, Bayesian nonparametric Gaussian process regression-based trajectory prediction models, and 4) a time-dependent collision probability map for conflict-free route generation. For physical flight testing, DNPRP will be evaluated by using a couple of multirotor UAVs that operate within an enclosed outdoor facility (i.e., the Virginia Tech Drone Park) for hours to days without human intervention. Trade-offs between computational cost and solution optimality in real-time operation will be assessed rigorously with measurable metrics, which will inform possible extensions to large-scale complicated systems. A rapid path for transitioning the research results to open-source or commercial software will be formed in close collaboration with an industrial partner.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
The key outcomes of this project include (1) a framework of algorithms for drone operations in a congested environment that seamlessly integrate target tracking of all neighboring small unmanned aerial systems (sUASs), generation of conflict-free optimal paths, and PID controller implementation, and (2) a fast-time sUAS trajectory generator and compile four-dimensional trajectory data to support the development of the deconfliction algorithms and a cloud-based database system to support sharing of real-time sUAS flight data. A software suite that implements components in (1) and (2) was completed. All programs were embedded into the UAS hardware via ROS/Mavros package for real-time sUAS flight tests.

With regard to the first effort, we first devised enhanced Gaussian process (GP) modeling and parallel particle filter-based (PF) methods, respectively, to enhance GP for high scalability and improved computational efficiency while working with streaming data and establish a high-probability credible bound for PF. Specifically, the proposed GP-based trajectory prediction approach features three novel components: uniform confidence bounds for simultaneous uncertainty quantification,  online trajectory change-point detection, and adaptive training data pruning.  The proposed parallel PF-based trajectory prediction approach incorporates the knowledge of specific sUAS types to better capture dynamics. It uses minimum volume enclosing ellipsoids to construct a high-probability credible bound for trajectory prediction that renders collision avoidance between sUASs with high confidence. Artificial intelligence-driven methods for trajectory modeling were also explored. As the information on other UAVs is accessible via the proposed cloud-based database system, that information can be utilized to model flight trajectories and predict future positions. Specifically, we created a dense layer comprising a convolutional neural network layer to account for the movement of other drones and used the encoder-decoder long short-term memory layer to predict the future position of specific sUASs. The development of a hybrid conflict-free path planner combines an artificial potential field (APF) method and the A*/D* algorithms. The APF method is fast in global search; still, it needs more robustness in finding local optimum, whereas the A*/D* algorithms are robust despite their high computational cost. The hybrid conflict-free route generator sequentially applies the APF method followed by the A*/D* algorithms to narrow down conflict-free areas in space over time and generates the optimal route of the minimal travel distance. A distributed operation version of the path planner applicable to an arbitrary number of UAVs was also implemented.

Regarding the second effort, a fast-time trajectory generation system (TG) for sUAS flight operations was developed; outputs from the TG will act as a surrogate for actual flight operations by providing high-fidelity flight trajectories of different mission attributes. Furthermore, the networked UAS baseline information store (NUBIS), a cloud-sourced, centralized database system that provides information services to support low-altitude sUAS operations, was developed. NUBIS can collect and archive flight states for a user-defined number of flights at a prescribed frequency and longitudinal period.

Finally, the initial development of an interface framework between a suite of software and the onboard UAS avionics system was investigated. The software includes Python codes to seamlessly enable the data communication between the airborne drones and the ground database server (NUBIS), the generation of flight trajectory, and the conflict-free, minimum-distance routes.

A dozen peer-reviewed publications in journals and conference proceedings were produced under this project. We presented the research at various scholarly conferences and workshops throughout the project duration.  The project facilitated a rapid transition of the research results into open-source or commercial software. This project provided training opportunities to several graduate and undergraduate students. In particular, two Ph.D. students and one M.S. student successfully defended their theses and completed their degrees; this project contributed significantly to their research skills and benefited their career placements.  

 


Last Modified: 01/13/2023
Modified by: Xi Chen
